awd_titl_txt: Positioning Youth for Success in Science: Studying the Malleability and Impact of Computational Thinking for Science
awd_abstract_narration:
As a result of the powerful innovation and application of computing in STEM disciplines, the STEM+C program addresses an urgent need for real-world, interdisciplinary, and computational preparation of students from the early grades through high school (preK-12). This project will advance research and development of new transdisciplinary approaches to computational STEM teaching and learning that will integrate the fields of computational thinking and science learning.  The project will synthesize across frameworks and definitions of computational thinking to identify those aspects that best position youth for future science learning.  The resulting construct, Computational Thinking for Science (CT-S) will be examined through the development of valid and reliable assessments, and the project team will investigate whether, for whom, and under what circumstances CT-S enables success in proximal science learning experiences. Findings will contribute to the field by describing the varied ways that students develop CT-S skill sets and the degree to which CT-S supports science learning and developing STEM career preferences. This will inform future curriculum and instructional development that integrates computational thinking and science learning in productive and supportive ways. This project is supported by the STEM + Computing Program that advances research and development of interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary approaches to the integration of computing within science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) teaching and learning for preK-12 students in both formal and informal settings. STEM+C supports research on how students learn to think computationally to solve interdisciplinary problems in the STEM fields.

The examination of CT-S will be embedded in a new Next Generation Science Standards-aligned, technology rich middle school science curriculum aimed at supporting the development of computational thinking. The research plan includes articulation of the CT-S construct and associated hypothetical learning progression, and development of CT-S assessment instruments embedded in three different science topics. These instruments will be validated via cognitive interviews with students, qualitative analysis of the pilot responses, and cross validated with student logs of simulations used in the curriculum. The project will use these instruments to conduct a multi-cohort one year longitudinal study with 1300 middle school students, exploring the relationship of CT-S with learning and career awareness outcomes and identify variations between subgroups. Data gathered over this longitudinal study will be analyzed through two analytical models. The first correlational model will examine CT-S as a predictor of engagement during learning experiences and science content learning. The second explores variations within and across individuals using HLM models to examine how CT-S changes during the middle grade years. Outcomes of this work will be shared to inform professional, practioner, and policy communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The growth of computers in all aspects of modern life has drawn increasing attention to how people should and do reason about computing.  Because computational models and simulations play a ubiquitous role in many science disciplines, it is increasingly important to make use of them in science learning. The project team investigated how to measure learning at the intersection of computational thinking and science, and developed a theory about the role learning at that intersection may play in positioning youth for success in future science learning. To accomplish this, the project synthesized frameworks and definitions of computational thinking to develop the construct of Computational Thinking for Science (CT-S) which includes the aspects that best position youth for future science learning. This construct was then operationalized through the development of a highly vetted assessment. Using this assessment we investigated whether, for whom, and under what circumstances higher scores on this assessment are associated with success in proximal science learning experiences. Findings contribute to the field by describing the degree to which CT-S supports science learning and developing STEM career preferences. Findings serve to inform future curriculum and instructional development that integrates computational thinking and science learning in productive and supportive ways. 


The research began with articulation of the CT-S construct and associated hypothetical learning progression. Next the team developed CT-S assessment instruments embedded in three different science topics. The examination of CT-S was embedded in a Next Generation Science Standards-aligned, technology rich middle school science curriculum that included opportunities to learn at the intersection of science and computational thinking. Through this project, we gathered validity evidence for these instruments via cognitive interviews with students, qualitative analysis of the pilot responses, and cross validated with student logs of digital scientific simulations used in the curriculum. The project then used these instruments to conduct a multi-cohort one year longitudinal study with approximately 1000 middle school students. This study explored the relationship of CT-S with learning and career awareness outcomes and identified variations between subgroups. 


We found that CT-S is predictive of learning science course content across diverse learning environments and for diverse learners. Further, across our diverse sample of learners we found that CT-S serves as a consistent predictor of science content learning across classroom settings (remote, hybrid, or in-person) and diverse science content areas (life, earth, or physical science). Further analysis demonstrated that the relationship between CT-S and science content learning is consistent across variations in students and classrooms, above and beyond STEM fascination or scientific sensemaking. This implies that CT-S and scientific sensemaking make complementary and independent contributions to supporting science content learning. After finding that CT-S was predictive of science learning across diverse learners, contexts, and content, we sought to understand how youth develop higher levels of CT-S. We first considered variations in the classroom environment and instruction. We found no associations of gains in CT-S with observed variations across classrooms. This result was not entirely unexpected. The study period was relatively brief, 1-3 months, and all study participants were using the same science curriculum. There may have been insufficient time for developing observable growth in CT-S over the study period, or too little variation in the way science was taught across classrooms to detect a difference. 


Our publicly available CT-S technical report (CITE/link) details the conceptualization, development, and validity evidence of the computational thinking for science assessment. We provide an operational definition of CT-S, describe the survey construction process, and provide validity evidence to support inferential claims from the survey about a middle school student’s computational thinking for science ability.


In working toward a reliable measure of CT-S, another important outcome of our work has been developing a theoretical framework for CT-S (Hurt, et al., 2023) that operationalizes the construct in ways that can support measurement development and instructional design. For researchers, this framework can be used to (a) identify science learning experiences that are likely to elicit computational thinking so that it can be investigated during those experiences and (b) inform the development of assessments aimed at revealing CT-S so that it can be measured. For designers of science learning experiences and K–12 science educators, the CT-S framework can support the development of learning experiences at the intersection of computational thinking and science.
